Setting Up Virtual Machine Using VirtualBox

Posted on December 30, 2017 by Kartik B. under Basic

VirtualBox allows you to run more than one operating system at a time. This way, you can run software written for one operating system on another (for example, Windows software on Linux or a Mac) without having to reboot to use it. Since you can configure what kinds of “virtual” hardware should be presented to each such operating system, you can install an old operating system such as DOS or OS/2 even if your real computer’s hardware is no longer supported by that operating system.

PREREQUISITES

To follow this tutorial, you will need:

  • A VIrtualBox compatible OS, check the compatible operating systems at https://www.virtualbox.org/wiki/Guest_OSes
  • An .ISO of the OS you want to install.

STEP 1 — DOWNLOADING THE VIRTUAL BOX

Virtualbox from oracle is available for free from the developer’s website at https://www.virtualbox.org/wiki/Downloads . Make sure that you download the correct version for your operating system.Once you are done with downloading install it.

STEP 2 — MAKING A NEW VIRTUAL MACHINE

 

Open your Oracle VM VirtualBox Manager.

 

Create new virtual machine by pressing the New button on the top left

 

A following menu will appear asking for the name of the VM and the OS you want to boot into. In this case I am going to install Windows 10, so for that select the type as Microsoft Windows and version as windows 10 (64-bit)

 

 

Next up, it will ask you about the memory size for the virtual host, Select the amount you want for it. I will go with the recommended size. Once you are done click Next

 

 

We are going to need some storage space for our virtual host. Choose the second option which is Create a virtual hard disk now and click Next

 

 

Keep the Hard Disk file type as VDI and click Next

 

 

Next up, choose if you want your disk to be dynamically allocated (that is it will be growing bigger when it needs to) or the fixed size which will limit the disk to a certain maximum value , I will be choosing the fixed size option.

Click Next

 

 

Select the size of the disk you’re creating (32 GB will be enough, but you can make it as much you want). Click on create and it will start creating the disk.

Once its done, it will throw you back to the main menu.

 

 

Click settings and select storage. Click on Empty below the .vdi disk that we created . In attributes, click the CD icon and select the ISO of your OS.

 

 

Click OK and now click on Start from the main menu .You will be prompted with setup of the selected operating system.

 

Congratulations, you have reached to the end of this guide. Hope you had fun installing with us. Subscribe here for more such guides.
